Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Refinement of the Floating Silicon Method to Produce Drop-In Silicon Wafers for High Efficiency Solar Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a 25% cost reduction in solar panel manufacturing and the elimination of up to 2.1 Gigatons of annual CO2 generation. As silicon wafers are the most expensive component in the $50BN solar panel industry, our low-cost wafer manufacturing technology presents the strongest opportunity to reduce global solar panel production costs. This cost reduction drives the compelling economics needed for increasing solar market penetration. As context, the solar market has historically doubled for every 20% cost reduction created by the industry. Our single crystal wafers are further significantly higher quality, and therefore can enable up to 10% higher effective efficiency using existing commercial solar panel manufacturing lines. Further, as the incumbent silicon wafer production process is extremely energy- and material-intensive and thus constitutes 80% of the solar industry?s carbon footprint, our direct and high efficiency technology has the potential to reduce the solar industry's 2026 carbon footprint by over 50%.

The proposed project develops the systems needed for our process to produce silicon wafers with commercial dimensions and demonstrates to solar manufacturers (our customers) that our wafers can be processed by commercial solar cell lines. As our process produces a continuous ribbon of silicon, this work will develop a cutting system that laser cuts discrete wafers with the edges and dimensions needed for commercial solar cell processing. This involves developing the laser cutting recipes, the wafer handling systems, and verifying with a third party that the edge quality does not interfere with cell processing. Our project then investigates and optimizes our wafers' performance during each critical step of commercial solar cell processing, including chemical etching and screen printing. A successful demonstration that our low-cost wafer can 'drop-in' to an existing cell line to deliver equivalent (or better) performance compared to the incumbent technology would gate our working with industry partners to commercialize this process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Floating Silicon Method (FSM) is a kerfless ribbon process to produce low-cost single crystal substrates for high efficiency silicon solar cells. This process reduces the all-in cost of solar manufacturing by 25% while also improving solar panel power by up to 7%.

The end-goal objective of this Phase I award was to advance FSM technology to the point where customer partnerships and technology demonstrations were possible. Early customer discussions revealed that partnership discussions were largely contingent on demonstrations that required minimal wafer quantities (>25 pieces) that our lab tool was not capable of producing (9 pieces max per run). This project was therefore scoped to design an original system that would enable the lab tool to produce wafers continuously, and therefore enable the necessary demo wafer quantities (>1000 pieces/run). Specifically, this involved developing a system that could continuously pull a silicon ribbon and laser singulate the moving ribbon into individual wafers.

Over the course of this we were able to successfully design, spec, build and test an original continuous puller and singulation system. Another solar equipment company had designed a robust factory ribbon puller system for a vertical ribbon process that had been demonstrated on over 500 working tools. To leverage that previous expertise, we sought out the same contract engineering firm to apply critical lessons learned and adapt to our horizontal ribbon growth process. This ribbon actuation system was built and a comprehensive acceptance test was performed to demonstrate key system requirements (like ribbon tension, ripple, gripping pressure) on the working setup.

We further developed a laser singulation system that could “cut-on-the-fly” wafers from a moving silicon ribbon. Working with a ribbon growth industry expert and with laser machining and applications experts, we tested out different lasers, recipes, and cut depths for singulating FSM wafers and thus identified the most cost-effective setup for our material needs. We further designed the on-tool laser-box to be safe, made sure it could be easily adjusted for process development, and are working to integrate the laser galvo software with our motion control system.

Commissioning, debugging, and optimizing this CP&S system was however fundamentally limited by the development and maturity of our original prototype tool. Our inherited lab tool did not have the necessary temperature control, which resulted in the majority of ribbons terminating during a run. The end-result was that the lab tool was not a reliable “test station” for commissioning this new continuous wafer production system. We therefore created an off-tool CP&S system acceptance test using ribbon material and steel sheets as proxies to demonstrate critical system specs as far as we could without actually using the system to pull the ribbon. These preliminary tests have all been successful and we feel confident in our using this new platform to continuously pull ribbon on a more stable ribbon growth tool. To overcome the inherent process instabilities, we decided to move to the next generation “Alpha” tool that overhauls hot zone architecture and temperature control schemes. We expect this new Alpha tool to be commissioned in June 2020, and we plan to commission and optimize the CP&S system by the end of 2020.
